triageAlgorithm.content:
If unstable, NBME usually wants stabilization before anything else:
- Airway/Breathing first (e.g., respiratory depression, tension pneumothorax)
- Circulation first (e.g., shock physiology)
- Cardiac membrane first when needed (e.g., hyperkalemia with ECG changes → IV calcium)

### Step 2: Is this a "can't-miss" surgical emergency?
When present, immediate surgical pathway overrides "best test" thinking:
- Bilious vomiting in neonate/young infant → volvulus until proven otherwise
- Testicular torsion pattern → urgent surgery evaluation
- Intussusception pattern → enema reduction (diagnostic + therapeutic)

commonTraps: - Wrong priority: insulin before fluids in DKA; antihistamines before epinephrine in anaphylaxis; imaging before decompression in tension pneumothorax
- Wrong timing: IgA nephropathy (during infection) vs PSGN (weeks later)
- Wrong physiology: serum hyperkalemia in DKA may reflect shift, not total-body excess
- Wrong site of care: neonates and unstable patients often require broader evaluation and higher-acuity management
- Normal variant vs pathology: common in pediatrics (development, sleep, newborn transitional findings)
